TIME NEWS TOUR OF THE FAR EAST

Welcome Aboard
Pan American World Airways is pleased to serve the
distinguished participants of Time, Inc.'s News Tour of
Southeast Asia.
This area is one of the last frontiers in our fast-changing
world, and we trust you will find this a most rewarding
journey. In the European-oriented world of not so long ago,
Asia was known as the Far East, but to America it is
the Far West - and not so very far at that. In this era of jets
and satellites, it is becoming "instant-Asia" to us.
The nations of Southeast Asia today are inviting new ideas
and welcoming new opportunities for constructive
development, and those of you who represent the highest
level of American Commerce, Finance and Industry will be
taking a close look at this aspect of the picture. In addition,
new vistas for both commerce and travel in Southeast
Asia await only an end to the Viet Nam war. We at Pan Am
are confident that you will return from the journey with
ideas that will be of value not only to the companies and
organizations that you represent, but to our nation and the
entire Free World.

Meet your flight service crew
IRA R. ANDERSEN, Assistant Chief Pilot,
Check and Training, Pacific. A highly skilled pilot,
Captain Andersen studied aeronautical engineering
at Sacramento Junior College and took his early
flight training under the Civilian Pilot Training
Program at Oakland's Tex Rankin School. He joined
Pan American in 1942 as flight instructor in flying
boats. Captain Andersen became well acquainted with
Pan Am's Latin America and Pacific routes in
the years following the war. He has flown a wide
variety of aircraft - Douglas DC-4's, Boeing
Stratocruisers and the 7UT, to name a Tew.
HENRY G. EVANS, Assistant Chief Pilot,
Pacific. A 27-year veteran with Pan American,
Captain Evans has flown the Pacific and Latin
American routes, is experienced in a wide variety
of aircraft from the Martin and Boeing Flying
Boats to the present-day 707's. A native of Oakland,
valit., ne noids a Master's degree in Economics
from the University of Florida. Captain Evans is
based in San Francisco, from where he supervises
Pan Am's far-ranging flight crews.
RICHARD L. ZARONES, First Officer. Mr.
Zarones is a specialist in navigation, in addition to
being a skilled pilot. He is Assistant Pilot-in-
Charge for Navigation, Pacific. During his years
with Pan Am, he has designed special equipment for
use in the company's thoroughgoing training
graduated from the University of Oregon, and
joined Pan American in 1955.
FITCH ROBERTSON, Flight Engineer. Mr.
Robertson is a 26-year veteran with Pan American.
He joined the company in 1943 after graduating
from Stanford University with a degree in
mechanical engineering. Mr. Robertson began his
career With an Am sung boats - poemnes and
Martins - and later moved into the Boeing 707
Intercontinental Jets.
ne noids a private plots
license, and weekend flying is a hobby.

FRANK PAPOUSCHEK. One of Pan Am's top
Check Pursers, Frank has flown the company's
global routes for nearly 11 years, knows the world
the the back Of his hand. A native of New Jersey,
he served as an Army sergeant in the Korean
wal.
studied general art at the Art School of
Philadelphia. During layovers between Pan Am
flights at his Bay Area home in Sausalito, Frank
sails and paints in his spare time, heads for the
snows on skiing expeditions in the winter months.
KATHLEEN MORGAN. A Pan American
purser from Seattle, Wash.,
Kathleen has been
flying with Pan Am on its global routes for "
years. She graduated from Washington State U. at
Pullman with a degree in Speech, and has been
airborne with Pan Am ever since.
GRY MOREN. A purser from Trysil, Norway,
Gry speaks six languages, plays the piano, indulges
her favorite sports of skiing and handball, and
relaxes with music, literature and the theater. With
Pan Am for six years, the tall Scandinavian left
a librarian's job in her home town to fly round the
world with Pan Am more times than she can
remember. But she still has her membership in the
"Trysil Sportsklubb."
ELLEN GANNON. Qualified in several fields,
Ellen picked flying with Pan Am. She has been with
the company since coming to work in 1965,
armed with a B.S. degree in Speech, Advertising and
Political Science from Northwestern University
in Evanston, Illinois. A native of Virginia, Ellen
has been active with the American Red Cross, Girl
Scouts, a full round of campus professional and
social activities when she was at Northwestern, and
today devotes her spare time to Art, Drama and
Modern Dance.

TRA THIEU DUONG. Petite, raven-haired
Tra Thieu forged her way with her family from
Hanoi in North Vietnam to Saigon, where her
mother today works at the U.s. Embassy. A one-time
Customer Service Representative with Air
vietnam, Ira Inieu switched to Pan Am and
went into stewardess training. Languages are her
noboy, along with sewing and painting. She nas
since travelled extensively throughout the Far East
from her base in san Francisco.
CAROL ANN MCBRIDE. With Pan American
for less than a year, Stewardess Carol Ann
has seen a lot of the world in a short time. She
came from Memphis, Tenn., where she graduated
from Memphis State U. with a B.A. in French.
Sewing, swimming, canoeing and camping number
amongst varol Ann's nobbies, and she plays plano
and the french horn as well. Why did she join
Pan Am? "To travel and meet interesting people."
EGON RASMUSSEN, Pan American's
Supervisor in the Pacific area was born in Denmark.
He has served in various Flight Service functions
in the New York area and for many years in the
Urent frior to mis employment with Pan American,
he served in the Danish Navy and as a Purser
with the Scandinavian Airhines System. Now an
American citizen he makes his home with his
wife Teresa in Hong Kong.
ANNA INGA TUFVESSON. Sweden's loss was
Pan Am's gain. Stewardess Anna is a newcomer to
Pan Am, bringing with her four college degrees
il the varlous Arts. bie wanted to be a stewardess
since she was a child, studied hard at the University
of Lund, went all-out in sking tennis. musie and
ballet, and landed in San Francisco, where she is now
based with Pan Am.
DOUGLAS M. MACKENZIE, Manager -
International Event Sales. Mr. MacKenzie, your
trip coordinator, is a native of Vancouver, Canada,
and assumed his present position with Pan
American in 1904. Before that he served in various
management capacities in the Yukon and Alaska,
me rappies, viet Nam, Indonesia and Malavsia.
for a total of 20 years. Mr. MacKenzie came to
New York to coordinate international event sales
embracing travel related to international expositions,
trade fairs, conventions and congresses and
special business trips. Among others he has handled
the Pan American Directors' annual trips since
1964 and the Time News Tour of Eastern Europe
in 1966. Doug and his wife Lucila have four children
and live in Huntington, New York.
